Headline.Para: Mixed trading day as Asia takes in news of rate hike

Snippet.Para: Main surprise is Fed's signal for 3 increases rather than 4 this year
Asian stocks ended mostly mixed as investors digested the implications of a widely expected rate hike from the Federal Reserve.

Code.CodeD: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System

Headline.Para: Mixed trading day as Asia takes in news of rate hike

LeadPara.Para: Main surprise is Fed's signal for 3 increases rather than 4 this year
Asian stocks ended mostly mixed as investors digested the implications of a widely expected rate hike from the Federal Reserve.

TailParas.Para: The US central bank raised interest rates on Wednesday and forecast at least two more hikes for the year, highlighting its growing confidence that tax cuts and government spending will boost the economy and inflation.
"The economic outlook has strengthened in recent months," the Fed said in a statement.
It said it had decided to raise its benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percentage point to a target range of 1.5 per cent to 1.75 per cent.
Policymakers also raised the forecast for rate hikes next year.
Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank was staying on a path of gradual rate increases but needed to be on guard against inflation.
POLICY TIGHTENING EXPECTED

Our expectation is that interest rates will go up faster than the Fed expects, and that policy will be tight before the end of 2019. This opens the possibility - certainly only a possibility at this stage - of recession in 2020, especially if fiscal policy is tightening in response to the blow-out in the budget deficit.
BANK OF SINGAPORE CHIEF ECONOMIST RICHARD JERRAM
"We are trying to take the middle ground here," he said at a press conference after the end of the policy meeting, according to Reuters.
He added that there were no signs the economy is on the cusp of accelerating inflation.
Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher but closed 0.56 per cent lower at 3,491.37.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index was 1.09 per cent down, while Japan's Nikkei 225 ended on a more positive note, at 0.99 per cent higher.
Gold also rose 1.15 per cent to reach US$1,330.85 per ounce.
Mr Powell, who officially took on his role at the Federal Reserve on Feb 3, also sounded a warning about rising trade tensions.
The Trump administration recently announced steel and aluminium tariffs and is weighing sanctions against China.
Mr Powell said a number of Fed officials have gathered from business leaders that "trade policy has become a concern going forward for that group".

Bank of Singapore chief economist Richard Jerram said the latest Fed policy announcement appears to confirm that Mr Powell's Fed will continue to raise interest rates slowly, while changes to the outlook will be "incremental and reactive".
Monetary policy is not set to turn "tight" until 2020, but Mr Jerram said interest rates will likely need to rise faster than the Fed suggests.
"Our expectation is that interest rates will go up faster than the Fed expects, and that policy will be tight before the end of 2019.
"This opens the possibility - certainly only a possibility at this stage - of recession in 2020, especially if fiscal policy is tightening in response to the blow-out in the budget deficit."

Mr Charles St-Arnaud, senior investment strategist at Lombard Odier Investment Managers, said the main surprise for many investors was that the Fed remains on track for three hikes this year rather than four.
"Many investors would have expected that the Fed would have upgraded its view given the stronger growth, the lower expected unemployment rate and improved economic outlook," he noted.
"In some ways, the increase in the rates path for 2019 may be the first step and that extra hike could be brought later this year.
"Our view remains that the Federal Reserve will hike its policy rate by three more hikes this year, as we believe that inflationary pressures are building up in the US."

Article.Art: US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaking at a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington on Wednesday. He said the central bank was staying on a path of gradual rate increases but needed to be on guard against inflation.
